children.title: black
children.comment: A dark colour often associated with impending judgment or with evil.

cschildren.title: Black as the opposite of light

primaryrefs.comment: Job cursing the day of his birth.

cschildren.title: Black in the setting of impending judgment
Black as a symbol of evil

children.title: blight
children.comment: A disease ruinous to crops. In the OT blight was seen as evidence of God's judgment.

cschildren.title: Blight as a symbol of sorrow

children.title: breath
children.comment: The imagery of breath is often used to convey spiritual essence and power, unseen except in its effects, including aspects of the person and work of the Holy Spirit. The main Hebrew and Greek words translated as ``breath'' in the NIV are also translated as ``spirit'' and ``wind''.

children.title: Life recalled by his sovereign will
An emblem of the Holy Spirit
clouds
children.comment: A natural feature of the sky, often associated with God's judgment, presence and glory.

children.title: Clouds subject to God's sovereign control
Clouds expressing the mystery of God's world

cschildren.title: Clouds as symbols of spiritual truths
Clouds as a symbol of God's presence and glory
Cold as part of the seasonal rhythm of the year
Cold as an aspect of the night
Cold as a source of discomfort
Cold as a source of refreshment

children.title: colours
children.comment: A wide range of colours are mentioned in Scripture, some being used symbolically.

primaryrefs.comment: An indication as to the season; the grass is green in Galilee in spring.

seealsos.comment: Purple, scarlet, crimson and red are closely related and sometimes interchangeable in Scripture

children.title: crimson
children.comment: A deep red colour used interchangeably with scarlet and sometimes with purple. It has associations with blood and richness.

cschildren.title: The richness of crimson used for ornamentation

primaryrefs.comment: It was used extensively in the construction of the tabernacle

cschildren.title: Crimson associated with splendour and prosperity
Crimson associated with blood and sin
Everyday use of the colour crimson

children.title: darkness
children.comment: The absence of light. Often used figuratively as a symbol of sin, chaos or the absence of God.

children.title: darkness, natural
children.comment: Scripture stresses that God is able to be present and known, even in the darkest aspects of the world.

children.title: Darkness as a symbol of the terrifying majesty of God
God is the source of natural darkness
darkness, as a symbol of sin
children.comment: Darkness is often used in Scripture as a symbol of sin and its effects. It is often contrasted with light, as a symbol of forgiveness and the presence of God.

children.title: Darkness as a symbol of sin
Darkness as a symbol of the effects of sin
Darkness symbolising ignorance of the truth
Darkness symbolising the inability to find the right way
Darkness symbolises death and the grave
God's provision for the darkness of sin
God himself is a remedy for darkness
God's Son saves believers from darkness
God's people rescue others from darkness
darkness, and God's judgment
children.comment: Darkness is used figuratively of God's present and final judgment upon individuals, unfaithful Israel and the heathen nations.

children.title: Darkness as a symbol of judgment upon ungodly individuals

seealsos.comment: Eliphaz reasons on the assumption that Job's suffering proves his wickedness

children.title: Darkness as a symbol of judgment upon unfaithful Israel

primaryrefs.comment: This will be fulfilled at the time of Israel's captivity.

children.title: Darkness as a symbol of judgment upon heathen nations
Darkness as a symbol of judgment at the day of the Lord
darkness, natural
children.comment: Scripture stresses that God is able to be present and known, even in the darkest aspects of the world.

children.title: Darkness as a symbol of the terrifying majesty of God
God is the source of natural darkness
darkness, as a symbol of sin
children.comment: Darkness is often used in Scripture as a symbol of sin and its effects. It is often contrasted with light, as a symbol of forgiveness and the presence of God.

children.title: Darkness as a symbol of sin
Darkness as a symbol of the effects of sin
Darkness symbolising ignorance of the truth
Darkness symbolising the inability to find the right way
Darkness symbolises death and the grave

God's people rescue others from darkness

children.comment: Darkness is used figuratively of God's present and final judgment upon individuals, unfaithful Israel and the heathen nations.

children.title: Darkness as a symbol of judgment upon ungodly individuals

seealsos.comment: Eliphaz reasons on the assumption that Job's suffering proves his wickedness

children.title: Darkness as a symbol of judgment upon unfaithful Israel

primaryrefs.comment: This will be fulfilled at the time of Israel's captivity.

children.title: Darkness as a symbol of judgment upon heathen nations
Darkness as a symbol of judgment at the day of the Lord

cschildren.title: Depth indicating the strength of human emotions
Depth as a characteristic of wisdom
Depth representating the immeasurability of God
Depth used to express the love of God
The nightly condensation of moisture from the atmosphere
Dew as a sign of God's blessing and provision
Lack of dew a sign of God's judgment

children.title: drought
children.comment: A severe long-term absence of water or drink of any kind, leading to disaster for the people affected in this way. Scripture provides examples of such droughts, while also indicating the possibility and dangers of long-term spiritual thirst arising through disobedience or lack of faith.

children.title: drought, physical
children.comment: Drought arises through the absence of rain, leading to severe hardship for those who are affected by it.

children.title: Drought may be a sign of God's displeasure
The response of believers to drought
It gives opportunity to help others
Rain is a sign of God's general favour or of his forgiveness
drought, spiritual
children.comment: Scripture indicates that believers, both as individuals and communities, may go through periods in which they fail to experience the refreshing and life-giving presence of God. One cause of such spiritual thirst is unbelief. Scripture also indicates ways in which this thirst may be relieved.

children.title: The remedy for spiritual drought is to be found in Jesus Christ
The experience of spiritual drought in believers
The cause of spiritual drought in believers
The remedy for spiritual drought in the lives of believers
drought, physical
children.comment: Drought arises through the absence of rain, leading to severe hardship for those who are affected by it.

children.title: Drought may be a sign of God's displeasure
The response of believers to drought
It gives opportunity to help others
Rain is a sign of God's general favour or of his forgiveness
drought, spiritual
children.comment: Scripture indicates that believers, both as individuals and communities, may go through periods in which they fail to experience the refreshing and life-giving presence of God. One cause of such spiritual thirst is unbelief. Scripture also indicates ways in which this thirst may be relieved.

children.title: The remedy for spiritual drought is to be found in Jesus Christ
The experience of spiritual drought in believers
The cause of spiritual drought in believers
The remedy for spiritual drought in the lives of believers
dryness
children.comment: A lack of moisture, often due to lack of rain or a period of drought, leading to vegetation drying up. Dryness is often used as a symbol of hopelessness or of the absence of God's blessing.

children.title: God's drying up of rivers to allow his people to cross
Other instances of rivers drying up

seealsos.comment: on the day of the LORD

cschildren.title: Dryness indicative of desolation and hopelessness
Dryness indicating God's withholding of moisture due to sin
Earthquakes as a demonstration of God's power
Elijah and the earthquake on Mount Horeb
The earthquake accompanying Jesus Christ's death and resurrection
Earthquakes among the signs of the end time

children.title: east
children.comment: The geographical direction often identified by the position of the rising sun. Many of Israel's invaders came from the east, often giving the term a negative association in OT writings.

cschildren.title: East as a point of the compass
East and west used to demonstrate vast extent
East identified by the rising sun

primaryrefs.comment: The east wind blows straight out of the desert

children.title: famine
children.comment: A severe long-term absence of food, leading to disaster for the people affected in this way. Scripture provides examples of such famines, while also indicating the possibility and dangers of spiritual famine arising through disobedience or lack of faith.

children.title: famine, physical
children.comment: A serious shortage of food caused by drought, war or natural disasters. Famine is seen as a sign of God's judgment on Israel.

children.title: In the days of the prophets
God's people seek him and return to him
famine, spiritual
children.comment: A state of spiritual hunger arising from a failure to experience the presence and joy of God. Scripture describes such experiences, indicates one ultimate cause to be unbelief and points to ways in which this famine can be relieved.

primaryrefs.comment: It is possible to be well-fed physically but famished spiritually.

children.title: Relief is promised to God's people
Final relief is found in heaven
Conditions of relief from spiritual famine
It is for those who desire it
It is for those who pray
It is for those who repent
It is for those who have patience
famine, physical
children.comment: A serious shortage of food caused by drought, war or natural disasters. Famine is seen as a sign of God's judgment on Israel.

children.title: In the days of the prophets
God's people seek him and return to him
famine, spiritual
children.comment: A state of spiritual hunger arising from a failure to experience the presence and joy of God. Scripture describes such experiences, indicates one ultimate cause to be unbelief and points to ways in which this famine can be relieved.

primaryrefs.comment: It is possible to be well-fed physically but famished spiritually.

children.title: Relief is promised to God's people
Final relief is found in heaven
Conditions of relief from spiritual famine
It is for those who desire it
It is for those who pray
It is for those who repent
It is for those who have patience
fire
children.comment: Scripture shows fire being used in a variety of ways in this world. Fire is often mentioned as a symbol, denoting God's presence and power, his judgment or his purifying work.

cschildren.title: Fire as an instrument of punishment
Fire as an instrument of divine judgment

children.title: frost
children.comment: A covering of the ground with fine particles of ice, characteristic of cold weather.

cschildren.title: Frost will be absent on the day of the LORD
Hail as a sign of the power of God
Hail as one of the ten plagues of Egypt
Hail as an aspect of the final divine judgment

seealsos.comment: Scorching heat was a curse for disobedience
relief from heat in the promised restoration of Israel
Jesus Christ on interpreting the times

cschildren.title: Heat associated with action in battle
Heat referring to animals entering period of fertility
Height in relation to physical stature
Height used to express the love of God

children.title: light
children.comment: The brightness that enables sight in the darkness. Scripture often uses light as a symbol of the saving presence of God in a fallen world, with darkness being used as a symbol of sin or the absence of God.

children.title: light, natural
children.comment: Scripture stresses that every source of light (sun, moon and stars) is created by God, and subject to him.

children.title: God is the source of natural light
The pillars of cloud and fire
light, spiritual
children.comment: Light is often used in Scripture as a symbol of the presence of God in the world. It is often especially associated with the word of God, the salvation brought about by God, or the person of Jesus Christ.

children.title: Light as a symbol of God
Satan as an imitator of light
Light as a symbol of God's favour towards his people
Light as a symbol of God's word
Light as a symbol of salvation
Light as a symbol of Jesus Christ
light, and people of God
children.comment: Scripture often uses light as a symbol of the people of God, and especially the manner in which believers are able and required to reflect the glory of God in a dark world of sin.

children.title: The people of God as the light of the world
Examples of believers acting as light to the world

secondaryrefs.comment: the righteous ruler, fully realised in Jesus Christ

children.title: God is the source of the light of his people
God and his law as the source of light
The gospel of forgiveness as a source of light
The people of God are called to live in his light
light, natural
children.comment: Scripture stresses that every source of light (sun, moon and stars) is created by God, and subject to him.

children.title: God is the source of natural light
The pillars of cloud and fire
light, spiritual
children.comment: Light is often used in Scripture as a symbol of the presence of God in the world. It is often especially associated with the word of God, the salvation brought about by God, or the person of Jesus Christ.

children.title: Light as a symbol of God
Satan as an imitator of light
Light as a symbol of God's favour towards his people
Light as a symbol of God's word
Light as a symbol of salvation
Light as a symbol of Jesus Christ
light, and people of God
children.comment: Scripture often uses light as a symbol of the people of God, and especially the manner in which believers are able and required to reflect the glory of God in a dark world of sin.

children.title: The people of God as the light of the world
Examples of believers acting as light to the world

secondaryrefs.comment: the righteous ruler, fully realised in Jesus Christ

children.title: God is the source of the light of his people
God and his law as the source of light
The gospel of forgiveness as a source of light
The people of God are called to live in his light

cschildren.title: Lightning as an aspect of heavy rain storms

children.title: A symbol of the power of God

cschildren.title: Lightning as a sign of the presence of God
A fungal plant disease, often seen as a sign of God's judgment

children.title: Mist as a source of water
Mist as a barrier to effective vision
Of a lack of substance or permanence
narrowness
children.comment: A state in which something is confined and restricted, lacking in breadth. It usually has pejorative implications, but Jesus Christ described the way of salvation in terms of narrowness.

cschildren.title: Narrowness in the architecture of the temple

children.title: north
children.comment: The geographical direction opposite to south, often used to demonstrate the vast extent between the two.

cschildren.title: North as a point of the compass

seealsos.comment: Although geographically situated to the east of Israel, invaders from Mesopotamia had to enter the country from the north, following the land route around the desert areas

cschildren.title: North and south used to demonstrate vast extent

children.title: plague
children.comment: Affliction with disease, destruction or environmental disaster as an expression of divine judgment, usually resulting in death. The purpose may be as a punishment or to encourage repentance.

children.title: Plagues withdrawn in answer to prayer
Plagues threatened for breaking God's covenant
Plagues experienced in fulfilment of God's covenant
Plagues withdrawn after intercession or obedience
Plagues announced by prophets as God's judgment

cschildren.title: Apocalyptic visions of plague as God's judgment

children.title: God's bounty in giving rain to Israel
God's bounty in giving rain to all humanity
God's punishment through rain and flood

cschildren.title: Rain as a symbol of spiritual truth

children.title: rainbow
children.comment: An arch of colours in the sky, formed by the sun's rays passing through raindrops. It was the sign of God's covenant with Noah, established in the aftermath of the great flood.

cschildren.title: The rainbow as a sign of God's covenant with Noah
The rainbow as a sign of God's glory

children.title: shadow
children.comment: Primarily a symbol of protection, of the brevity of life and of the experience of death, in contrast to God's character and work.

cschildren.title: Shadow as a general symbol of protection

children.title: A symbol of the protection given by God's chosen one

cschildren.title: Shadow as a symbol of life
Shadow as a symbol of the experience of death

children.title: Shadow contrasts with God's unchanging nature
God's salvation reaches to those whose life is in shadow

cschildren.title: OT ceremonies as a shadow of the reality in Jesus Christ
Smallness with regard to importance and social standing
Smoke associated with the divine presence

seealsos.comment: the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah

cschildren.title: Smoke associated with the offering of incense
Snow all year round on Mount Lebanon
Snow as a symbol of whiteness
Snow as a symbol of purity

children.title: south
children.comment: The geographical direction opposite to north, often used to demonstrate the vast extent between the two.

cschildren.title: South as a point of the compass
South and north used to demonstrate vast extent
Thunder as an aspect of violent weather
Thunder as a sign of the presence of God
Thunder as an expression of the judgment of God

children.title: weather
children.comment: Patterns of climatic conditions, such as wind and rain, which were of major importance to the rural economies of the Near East. Scripture stresses the sovereignty of God over the weather and sees it as a possible means of judgment or reward.

children.title: weather, God's sovereignty over
children.comment: The weather is under the control of God, who alone is able to direct it.

children.title: The weather is under God's control
God alone understands the mysteries of the weather
Israel's economy was dependent on the weather
The weather demonstrates God's goodness and mercy
The weather as a demonstration of God's direct intervention
The weather as an answer to prayer
weather, as God's judgment
children.comment: The weather can be seen as an expression of God's judgment and grace, as well as providing insights concerning human nature.

children.title: The weather as an expression of God's judgment
The weather as a source of spiritual insight
About the signs of the times
weather, God's sovereignty over
children.comment: The weather is under the control of God, who alone is able to direct it.

children.title: The weather is under God's control
God alone understands the mysteries of the weather
Israel's economy was dependent on the weather
The weather demonstrates God's goodness and mercy
The weather as a demonstration of God's direct intervention
The weather as an answer to prayer
weather, as God's judgment
children.comment: The weather can be seen as an expression of God's judgment and grace, as well as providing insights concerning human nature.

children.title: The weather as an expression of God's judgment
The weather as a source of spiritual insight
About the signs of the times
west
children.comment: The geographical direction often identified by the position of the setting sun.

cschildren.title: West as a point of the compass
West and east used to demonstrate vast extent
West identified by the setting sun

children.title: whirlwind
children.comment: A violent wind, often associated with the presence and activity of God.

cschildren.title: The presence of God in whirlwinds

children.title: In taking Elijah up to heaven

cschildren.title: Whirlwinds as symbols of disaster or divine judgment

children.title: white
children.comment: A symbol of purity and regeneration reflecting godliness, and also a symbol of victory.

children.title: wind
children.comment: In Hebrew the same word can denote ``breath'', ``wind'' or ``spirit''. Scripture describes the powerful effect of wind, and uses the image figuratively to speak of God's power and presence in the world.

seealsos.comment: A wind caused the flood waters to recede
An east wind brought the plague of locusts on Egypt
A wind brought quail to feed the Israelites

children.title: As an image of the Holy Spirit

primaryrefs.comment: The Greek word for ``Spirit'' is the same as that for ``wind'', allowing Jesus Christ to play on the double meaning of the word.

children.title: As an image of spiritual instability
As an image of something insubstantial
